subdebateinfo.title: AUSTRALIAN ARMY: MEDICAL CATEGORIES; LEAVE TO ATTEND FUNERALS.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for the Army, upon notice -

item.para: What percentage of members of the Australian Military Forces are classified in medical categories Bl or B2?
How many ex-members of the Second Australian Imperial Force have been called up for service in the Australian Military Forces?

talk.start.para: - The answers to the honorable member's questions are as follows : -

item.para: The information requested regarding the percentage of members of the Australian Military Forces classified in medical categories Bl or B2 is not available. Initially, the medical standards for the Australian Imperial Force and the Citizen Military Forces were different. Subsequently, the medical classifications were standardized, but personnel were not reclassified according to the new standards unless occasion arose for a member to appear before a medical board. A test check of a largo number of personal records suggests that approximately thirteen (13) per cent, of the members of the Australian Military Forces are in medical categories which under the present classification would be class B.
The information requested regarding the number of ex-members of the Second Australian Imperial Force called up for service in the Australian Military Forces is not available.

answer.para: At the 30th January, 1943, Army statistics disclosed that 4,155 ex-members of the Second Australian Imperial Force had re-enlisted or been called up for service in the Australian Military Forces, but there is no record of the number of those who were volunteers and those who were called up.

On the 24th February, the honorable member for Wilmot (Mr. Guy) asked me whether it was a fact that members of the Australian Imperial Force and Citizen Military Forces who are granted special leave to attend the funeral of a deceased relative had their pay stopped for the period of their absence.
I am now able to inform the honorable member as follows: -

item.para: Any member of the Australian Military Forces may he granted leave with pay for a period which will permit the member to spend three clear days at the place at which the death occurred, in the case of the death of a member'sspouse, child, parent, or other near dependent relative.
Such leave is at the discretion of the member's Commanding Officer, who must take into consideration the exigencies of the military situation in dealing with an application for leave.
Leave may be granted in excess of the three days referred to above, where necessary, in which case the excess period only is without pay.
Leave without pay cannot be compulsorily imposed, but it is granted only on the written application of the member specifying that leave is desired without pay.

answer.para: It will be noted that this special compassionate leave is granted only in the case of the death of a dependent relative. The case referred to by the honorable member may have been that of a nondependent relative in which case the above conditions are not applicable. If the honorable member so desires, I shall be glad to inquire into any individual case 'which he considers has resulted in hardship to the member concerned.

talk.start.para: - On the 4th March, 1943, the honorable member for Wentworth (Mr. Harrison) asked the following question, upon notice: -

item.para: Has the Prime Minister any information to give the House concerning the strike at the Maitland Main Colliery on the 24th February, because one man had reached the age of 60, and ./as therefore retired under the pensions scheme ?

Will the Prime Minister have an investigation made into stoppages at this mine and call for a report concerning the activities of the secretary of Maitland Main Miners' Lodge, Mr. Orr, in relation to this and other recent strikes at this colliery?

question.para: I desire to inform the honorable member that inquiries have been made and that I am now in a position to- furnish the following reply : -

item.para: A stoppage of work occurred at Maitland Main Colliery on the 24th February, because the lodge members refused to continue at work with a man then aged 60 years, who was due for retirement under the compulsory retirement provisions of the New South Wales Coal and Shale Mine-workers' Pensions Act, but whose application for exemption from retirement nad been approved by the tribunal established under that act to deal with such applications.
An investigation has been made into stoppages at this mine and reports furnished to the authority appointed to deal with these matters.
